quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: But investors also gave really helpful feedback and feedback. Often in the form of rejection, they would say, "Oh, your market's not big enough," and I would say, "It's going to be huge." And I'd add a new page in my pitch deck that said how big the market I believe was, and then they'd say, "You're the same as some of other company." And I would say, "Hey, now I've got a new slide in my pitch deck that shows all the players and the huge gap in the market that we believe we're going to fill."
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A practical fundraising loop: treat rejections as structured feedback and systematically update your pitch to address each objection.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The thing that I love about a crazy big goal is that you feel completely inadequate before it. You want to work really hard to will it into existence.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for setting goals that create urgency and ambition by design.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: So we have this concept of chaos to clarity. Every idea starts in the chaos side, and then you have to work all the way to the other side, which is clarity.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A simple framework for product/project work that normalizes early ambiguity and emphasizes the journey toward crisp execution.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: That very first step at the far end of chaos was quite an embarrassing step actually, because you don't have mastery at that point. You don't have all the answers.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: Counterintuitive encouragement to start before you’re ready—embracing discomfort as a sign you’re doing real early-stage work.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Their team spent two years rewriting their entire code base and were unable to ship any new features for over two years, something they expected to just take six months, and they even went through a big pivot early on from a yearbook publishing platform to the Canva that you know today,
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete example of how major rewrites and pivots can take far longer than planned—and still underpin long-term success.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Vanta helps companies of all sizes get compliant fast and stay that way with industry leading AI, automation and continuous monitoring.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical approach to compliance as an ongoing, automated process rather than a one-time project.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Vanta also helps you complete security questionnaires up to five times faster so that you can win bigger deals sooner.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Connects operational efficiency (faster questionnaires) directly to revenue outcomes (closing larger deals).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: According to a recent IDC study, Vanta customers slashed over $500,000 a year and are three times more productive.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete benchmark for the potential ROI of automating trust/compliance workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Last year, 1.3% of global GDP flow through Stripe. That's over $1.4 trillion.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A striking scale data point that signals Stripe’s reach and reliability as infrastructure.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Founders enrolled in Stripe Startups get access to credits to offset Stripe fees, expert insights, and a focused community of other founders building on Stripe.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Summarizes a repeatable support model for early-stage teams: reduce costs, learn faster, and leverage peer networks.

quotes.topic_title: Column B thinking: dream future, work backward
quotes.text: So I guess there's two ways of planning. The way that you can plan is you can dream of what is the perfect vision of the future, what future do you want to exist in, what would you like the world to look like? What would you like companies to look like? And then going from there, which is completely improbable, a completely crazy big dream, and then working hard to turn that into reality.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: Defines the core “Column B” planning method: start from an ideal future and work backward into execution.

quotes.topic_title: Column B thinking: dream future, work backward
quotes.text: And the other thing you can do is you can look at the bricks around you and you can say, "What can I do with these bricks? How high can I stack them? What can I do?" And I think most planning is often done by looking at the bricks and trying to stack them, and then you can create only so much.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: Contrasts constraint-led planning with vision-led planning, arguing the former caps outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Column B thinking: dream future, work backward
quotes.text: And so I guess the column B thinking is thinking about what is that magical wonderful future that you then want to invest years and decades of your life actually building?
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: Turns “Column B” into a practical filter for long-term founder commitment and prioritization.

quotes.topic_title: Column B thinking: dream future, work backward
quotes.text: So column A would've been nothing frankly, because the reality was when I was a university student with no company and no business or product or software experience, the reality would've been not very much. And so it was all column B, it was all thinking about the wild future that we wanted to create.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A concrete example of using future-back planning when present-day resources/credentials are minimal.

quotes.topic_title: Column B thinking: dream future, work backward
quotes.text: And it just seemed so apparent to me that in the future it was going to be completely different. Could I build that future? I had absolutely no idea, but the idea, it seemed completely likely, completely improbable that it wouldn't be the case that in the future, design would be online and collaborative and really simple.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: Captures the conviction-driven bet behind Canva: treat a major shift as inevitable and build toward it despite uncertainty.

quotes.topic_title: How to build Column B: vision to ladder
quotes.text: And I think an exercise we often do is what is wild success for X, or what is wild success for Y? And then equally, what is terrible failure for those things?
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: Introduces a concrete planning exercise that clarifies both the desired outcome and what to avoid over a long horizon.

quotes.topic_title: How to build Column B: vision to ladder
quotes.text: And I think just taking that very long timescale of 10 years and getting a really crisp idea of what you want, of what you don't want, that's sort of the first step.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: Emphasizes a 10-year horizon as a practical way to sharpen vision before execution.

quotes.topic_title: How to build Column B: vision to ladder
quotes.text: You kind of want to have a ladder that goes all the way up to the moon, which is your crazy, wild vision. And then you want to have rungs that just work its way up step by step.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: Provides a memorable mental model for translating a moonshot vision into incremental, executable steps.

quotes.topic_title: How to build Column B: vision to ladder
quotes.text: And so I think actually just making time to spend thinking about that is probably one of the most critical pieces.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: Highlights that the scarce resource isn’t ideas but protected time to think beyond day-to-day noise.

quotes.topic_title: How to build Column B: vision to ladder
quotes.text: even if that is so big and so vast and so wild, having that very first step is so important because then you take that little tiny first step and then the next step then that compounds for us, it's been compounding over a decade as we continue to work towards that same mission and vision.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: Connects tiny initial actions to long-term compounding progress as the mechanism for making big visions real.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing ideas: chaos-to-clarity vision decks
quotes.text: So we have this concept of chaos to clarity and every idea starts in the chaos side, and then you have to work all the way to the other side, which is clarity.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: Introduces Canva’s core framework for turning vague ideas into something executable.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing ideas: chaos-to-clarity vision decks
quotes.text: And so the idea is that each little step from chaos to clarity is the very first step might be literally writing it down.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, low-friction first action to move an idea out of your head and into progress.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing ideas: chaos-to-clarity vision decks
quotes.text: And then as it kind of goes from chaos to clarity, it starts to become more and more real and more and more people can see it.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: Explains why iterating toward clarity unlocks alignment and collaboration as a forcing function.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing ideas: chaos-to-clarity vision decks
quotes.text: So I think that's why visual communication for us is so important, is because otherwise, if it's just in your head, no one else can see it and you can't will it into existence.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: Highlights a practical principle: making ideas visible is essential for execution and buy-in.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing ideas: chaos-to-clarity vision decks
quotes.text: And I think that's the thing is that that very first step at the very far end of chaos, it's very embarrassing because you're like, "I have this idea that is so big and so wild and how the hell would I do that? I have no idea."
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: Normalizes the discomfort of early-stage ideation and reframes it as an expected part of the process.

quotes.topic_title: Crazy Big Goals: setting, measuring, celebrating
quotes.text: But I think with a crazy big goal, then you want to work really hard to will it into existence.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A simple mental model: ambitious goals require deliberate, sustained effort rather than passive planning.

quotes.topic_title: Crazy Big Goals: setting, measuring, celebrating
quotes.text: And so a crazy big goal is both crazy big, but it's also something that you think is incredibly important that you actually want to will into existence because it is so much work to will a crazy big goal into existence. So it better be one that you want to actually achieve.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A practical filter for goal-setting: only pick “crazy big” goals you care enough about to endure the work.

quotes.topic_title: Crazy Big Goals: setting, measuring, celebrating
quotes.text: So we have our mission to empower the world to design and we break it down into mission pillars. So empower everyone to design anything with every ingredient in every language on every device, obviously a mouthful.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A scalable framework for execution: translate a broad mission into concrete “pillars” that can be measured and staffed.

quotes.topic_title: Crazy Big Goals: setting, measuring, celebrating
quotes.text: The timeframe that we achieve them on has not always been very reliable.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: Counterintuitive expectation-setting: you can hit ambitious outcomes while being consistently wrong on timelines.

quotes.topic_title: Crazy Big Goals: setting, measuring, celebrating
quotes.text: But they're such an important goal that even if you make a little step in their direction, they're worthwhile nonetheless.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A resilience principle for long-horizon goals: progress can be valuable even when the end-state may be unreachable.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling pains and the two-year rewrite tunnel
quotes.text: Every time the company doubles in size, pretty much all your systems break, all the things that were working don't work.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A scaling mental model: expect process and communication systems to fail at each doubling and proactively redesign them.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling pains and the two-year rewrite tunnel
quotes.text: But then they started to become six hours long because we had so many people and so many teams.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A concrete example of how rituals that create alignment can become a bottleneck as headcount and team count grow.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling pains and the two-year rewrite tunnel
quotes.text: we were doing a front-end rewrite and we thought it would take about six months. It was really important because it was critical for cross-platform. It was critical for right to left. It was critical because we could only have five people working in our editor at any point in time because of the way the code base was structured and we thought it was going to take six months and then it took two years and it was two years of not shipping any product, two years of a product company not being able to ship product.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A vivid cautionary tale about rewrite timelines and the organizational cost of architectural constraints (e.g., only five engineers able to work in the editor).

quotes.topic_title: Scaling pains and the two-year rewrite tunnel
quotes.text: we tried to make it fun for the team. So it was partly fun and it was partly distressing as all of our investors were like, "Hey, that thing." So I think it was both things at the same time. It was bonding let's say.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A practical morale tactic for long, painful projects: deliberately gamify progress while acknowledging external pressure.

quotes.topic_title: 100+ investor rejections: iterate the pitch, not ego
quotes.text: But investors also gave really helpful feedback and feedback often in the form of rejection.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: Reframes fundraising “no’s” as a structured feedback channel you can systematically learn from.

quotes.topic_title: 100+ investor rejections: iterate the pitch, not ego
quotes.text: So they would say, "Oh, your market's not big enough." And I would say, "It's going to be huge." And I'd add a new page in my pitch deck that said how big the market I believe was.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A concrete iteration loop: turn each objection into a specific pitch-deck improvement that pre-answers the next investor’s concern.

quotes.topic_title: 100+ investor rejections: iterate the pitch, not ego
quotes.text: And so being able to take all the gems of wisdom from that conversation and have that understood really clearly in a really short period of time and have all of the reasons that people were rejecting us pre-answered in that initial pitch deck was really important.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A methodology for reducing time-to-understanding: compress hard-won clarity into the deck so you don’t need hours of explanation.

quotes.topic_title: 100+ investor rejections: iterate the pitch, not ego
quotes.text: It was pretty consistent, but the way we articulated it changed greatly.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: Separates vision from communication—keep the core steady while aggressively iterating the narrative.

quotes.topic_title: 100+ investor rejections: iterate the pitch, not ego
quotes.text: And so then the first few pages became very much more problem-based because if people don't understand the problem then they can't understand or care about your solution.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: Actionable pitch guidance: lead with problem framing to make the solution legible and compelling.

quotes.topic_title: Fundraising advice: control what you can
quotes.text: I think just taking the rejection and turning into things that you can control.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A simple control-the-controllables mindset for turning fundraising rejection into productive iteration.

quotes.topic_title: Fundraising advice: control what you can
quotes.text: So I can control my pitch deck, I can control the number of people I'm speaking to and I just spoke to literally everyone.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: Actionable fundraising levers: improve the deck and increase conversation volume to raise odds of finding a fit.

quotes.topic_title: Fundraising advice: control what you can
quotes.text: And I think that continuing to use it to refine it rather than taking it as a personal rejection, I think it's really important to think how can I improve?
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: Reframes rejection as feedback for iteration, reducing emotional drag and increasing learning speed.

quotes.topic_title: Fundraising advice: control what you can
quotes.text: I remember pitching an investor that had the lean startup book behind them when I was pitching them and they were never going to like Canva.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A concrete example of investor mismatch: some rejections are about philosophy/fit, not quality.

quotes.topic_title: Fundraising advice: control what you can
quotes.text: So there's some people that are just going to never like you and that's okay.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: Counterintuitive permission to stop trying to convince everyone and instead focus on aligned investors.

quotes.topic_title: Leadership growth: authenticity over imported playbooks
quotes.text: And it's kind of building a house that you want every brick in the house to match. And if you go and try and take some bricks from someone else's house and stick it in your house, it's probably going to not look very matched.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why importing other companies’ processes often clashes with your organization’s culture and context.

quotes.topic_title: Leadership growth: authenticity over imported playbooks
quotes.text: And so trying to find things that are authentic to us and are authentic to everything that's come before it, is just that constant, constant thing.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: Highlights the ongoing leadership work of evolving systems that fit your company’s DNA rather than chasing external best practices.

quotes.topic_title: Leadership growth: authenticity over imported playbooks
quotes.text: And so you kind of think about it in the very early days. We just a few of us, two of us in Fusion and then three of us in a little tiny group, and you kind of wear a hundred hats and then you have to be able to give away those hats to other people that can then do that way better than yourself.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A practical scaling framework: leadership growth requires deliberate delegation to people who outperform you in specific “hats.”

quotes.topic_title: Leadership growth: authenticity over imported playbooks
quotes.text: And there was many, many times over the years that we didn't have confidence in the way we were doing things and we were like, "Oh, they've done it from a big company that's bigger than our company. Let's go do that." And that hasn't always worked out so well for us.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that copying “big company” playbooks can fail—and that confidence in your own approach is a key scaling skill.

quotes.topic_title: Leadership growth: authenticity over imported playbooks
quotes.text: It feels like, as I was saying before, systems break and need to be reinvented but also reimagined for that next layer of scale rather than going to try to get something off the shelf from another company.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: An actionable methodology for scaling: expect systems to break and proactively redesign them for the next stage instead of adopting off-the-shelf solutions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: JustWorks knows that your employees are more than just your employees, they're your people.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable people-first framing that encourages leaders to treat HR decisions as human support, not just administration.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: My team is spread out across Colorado, Australia, Nepal, West Africa and San Francisco.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete example of a globally distributed team that highlights the operational reality practitioners may need to design for.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: My life would be so incredibly complicated to hire people internationally to pay people on time and in their local currencies and to answer their HR questions 24/7.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Calls out the key execution pitfalls of international hiring—payroll, currency, and always-on HR support—so teams can plan for them explicitly.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: But with JustWorks, it's super easy whether you're setting up your own automated payroll, offering premium benefits or hiring internationally.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: An actionable menu of HR capabilities (payroll, benefits, international hiring) that can be bundled to reduce operational overhead.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: They do your human resources so that you can do right by your people, JustWorks, for your people.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A clear delegation principle: outsource HR complexity to focus leadership attention on employee experience and outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Mission-to-goals operating system and authenticity
quotes.text: So the mission, actually breaking that down into the mission pillars, breaking those mission pillars down into the goals that we're then pursuing and then celebrating those goals when we do achieve them, I think is a deeply underloved way of building a company.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A concrete operating system for translating a mission into day-to-day execution and reinforcement.

quotes.topic_title: Mission-to-goals operating system and authenticity
quotes.text: Often people have a mission that's kind of on the wall somewhere and then what they're actually doing and the way they actually make money and the way people actually spend their time is in a very, very different direction from that original mission.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: Highlights a common failure mode where mission statements drift from incentives and daily work.

quotes.topic_title: Mission-to-goals operating system and authenticity
quotes.text: And I think the magic is when you can bring those two things together and so you can have your mission, you can have your mission pillars that actually are helping to achieve that.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for aligning mission, pillars, and execution into one coherent system.

quotes.topic_title: Mission-to-goals operating system and authenticity
quotes.text: And I think there's a real authenticity in that for customers as well, is that you are actually doing the thing that you promised you do, and it all ladders up together.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: Connects internal alignment directly to external trust—customers feel authenticity when actions match promises.

quotes.topic_title: Mission-to-goals operating system and authenticity
quotes.text: It's certainly not an easy way to run a company, but I think that when you do get that formula, I think that there's a lot of authenticity with what you're saying you're doing, you're actually doing.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that harder operational discipline can produce stronger credibility and clarity.

quotes.topic_title: Sustainable pace: boundaries, habits, perspective
quotes.text: But when you've been doing this for a while, if you just keep working at that pace, I don't think it's good for anyone's health, mental health or anything else.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A clear warning that sustained “always on” intensity has real health and performance costs over the long run.

quotes.topic_title: Sustainable pace: boundaries, habits, perspective
quotes.text: I don't have emails on my phone and so when I shut my laptop, I actually tune out and then if there's a real issue, I'll get an emergency call or page.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A concrete boundary-setting tactic (remove email from phone) paired with an escalation path for true emergencies.

quotes.topic_title: Sustainable pace: boundaries, habits, perspective
quotes.text: So when I'm working, I'm all in and then when I'm not working, I'm all out.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A simple, memorable operating principle for creating clean on/off modes and protecting recovery time.

quotes.topic_title: Sustainable pace: boundaries, habits, perspective
quotes.text: So when they're working every weekend it feels like the right thing, but then sometimes you can miss the forest from the trees when you're just working harder and harder, but maybe you're actually working on the wrong thing.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that more effort can reduce effectiveness if it crowds out reflection and prioritization.

quotes.topic_title: Sustainable pace: boundaries, habits, perspective
quotes.text: And so I think being able to step away a little just to be able to get perspective is actually really beneficial.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A practical mental model: stepping away isn’t slacking—it’s a tool for regaining strategic clarity.

quotes.topic_title: Community-driven product: closing the loop at scale
quotes.text: We've been doing it for years now, and so we get more than a million requests from our community every year and we've got a whole incredible team that then tallies them, breaks them down, and then delivers them to all of our product teams and then those actually get closed. So this year we've closed more than 200 loops, but we know that each one of those things is going to be loved and needed by so many more people that don't bother to actually fill out the request form.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A concrete, scalable operating model for routing community feedback into product execution, with specific volume and throughput metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Community-driven product: closing the loop at scale
quotes.text: I think there's two parts to product. One is building the future and towards the mission and the mission pillars as I was saying before. And the other is actually listening to our community and building what they want. And so I think that that's the two core pieces of product in my mind.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A simple two-part product framework that balances mission-led innovation with community-driven prioritization.

quotes.topic_title: Community-driven product: closing the loop at scale
quotes.text: And if people hesitate clicking a button or people don't quite understand how something works, it's amazing to me how you can find 10 random people on the internet and they can give such astute feedback that then is so representative for such a large number of people.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A practical user-testing heuristic: small, fast tests with “random” users can surface broadly representative UX issues.

quotes.topic_title: Community-driven product: closing the loop at scale
quotes.text: So people are so much more frank I think when it's just them and their camera and they don't really... Yeah, they tell you really how it is.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation that remote testing can produce more honest feedback than in-person sessions.

quotes.topic_title: Two-step plan: build value, then do maximum good
quotes.text: Step one, build one of the world's most valuable companies and step two, do the most good we can do.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A simple two-step framework that pairs company-building ambition with explicit social impact as a core goal.

quotes.topic_title: Two-step plan: build value, then do maximum good
quotes.text: And in our early days I thought I'd do step one and then step two and realize that actually step one can fuel step two and step two can fuel step one.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A counterintuitive insight that impact and business growth can be mutually reinforcing rather than sequential.

quotes.topic_title: Two-step plan: build value, then do maximum good
quotes.text: Every single person, every single company should take that where you give 1% of time, money, equity and profitability.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: Actionable advice: adopt a concrete, easy-to-start giving mechanism early so it compounds over time.

quotes.topic_title: Two-step plan: build value, then do maximum good
quotes.text: So Cliff and I owned a little over 30% of Canva, and so we decided we were going to take 30% of Canva and use it to do the most good we can do.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A specific, high-commitment example of tying long-term impact to equity rather than only cash donations.

quotes.topic_title: Two-step plan: build value, then do maximum good
quotes.text: We've just, over the last few years, we've donated $50 million to GiveDirectly, where they give money directly to people in Malawi who are in extreme poverty and then they can use that money on their family to go to school, to get healthcare, to start small businesses, to get a roof so they can sleep in without being wet.
quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.context: A concrete data point and operating model (direct cash transfers) showing how large-scale giving can be deployed with clear end-use outcomes.
